issues.description: The problem statement (UML and textual description) and the template/Main usage expect Milkable.messageOnMilk() to be a no-argument method returning a String (e.g., "[Animal Type] [name] is milked"). However, the solution repository defines the Milkable interface as messageOnMilk(double volume) (adds a double parameter) and the Seal/Goat implementations use this parameter and include volume in the returned string. Additionally, the commented example usage in Main (both template and solution Main) calls messageOnMilk() with no arguments, which contradicts the solution interface. This parameter mismatch will confuse students about the correct method signature to implement and prevents direct use of the provided example Main code or straightforward comparison to the UML/specification.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the Milkable API consistent across artifacts. Recommended: change the solution to match the problem/template by defining Milkable.messageOnMilk() with no parameters returning String, and update Seal and Goat implementations to return the specified string format (e.g., "Seal Clarabelle is milked"). Also ensure the example usage in Main matches the no-arg signature. Alternatively, if the intended design is to include a volume parameter, update the problem statement UML, the template Main example, and textual description to describe messageOnMilk(double) and show example calls with a volume argument.

issues.description: The problem specification and UML require a Milkable.messageOnMilk() method with no parameters that returns a String (e.g. "[Animal Type] [name] is milked"). The solution repository defines Milkable.messageOnMilk(double volume) (and Seal/Goat implement this signature), introducing a parameter that is not present in the problem. The template's Main (commented example) and the problem text expect a no-argument messageOnMilk() call. This signature mismatch (same conceptual method with different parameters) creates a mapping barrier: students following the problem/template will implement or call messageOnMilk() without arguments, while the solution uses a different API, causing confusion and breaking direct correspondence between requirements, starter code, and reference implementation.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the Milkable API across artifacts. Either (A) change the solution to match the problem/template by removing the double parameter: define Milkable.messageOnMilk() returning a String and update Seal/Goat implementations to return "[Animal Type] [name] is milked" with no volume; or (B) update the problem statement and template examples to specify messageOnMilk(double volume) and the expected string including the volume. Option A is recommended to preserve the problem's specified method signature and avoid forcing students to handle an unexpected parameter.
